Description: Fragment of large terracotta figurine: webbed foot of an aquatic bird (?), or the claw/paw of a great cat (?); underside flat, irregular. The tips of three of the four claws are broken off. Mould-made. Orange-brown clay, relatively fine, little mica.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by University of Pennsylvania Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology, Philadelphia. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Egypt Exploration Fund Philadelphia distribution list no. 29. Probably not locally produced. A very similar, but smaller, mould is in Alexandria Greco-Roman Museum (Seif el-Din 1998, 176-7, fig.14) dated to 'probably Roman' period. Identical piece from Naukratis, made of local Nile Silt fabric, is in Boston, Museum of Fine Arts (RES.87.158). Similar piece from Memphis, but different mould series, dated to the Roman period in the Petrie Museum (UC50464). Seif el-Din, M. 1998. The Gayer-Anderson collection of plaster moulds in the Greco-Roman Museum of Alexandria, in Empereur, J-Y. (ed.), Commerce et Artisant dans l’Alexandrie Hellénistique et Romaine, Paris, 165-204.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.284) (Phase 1)
